discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct, distriutable streaming commands are executed both on SH and IDX (It depends on the order of commands). If any of the preceding commands execute on the SH then the distributable streaming command als oexecutes on SH (i.e. if we have a centralized streaming command BEFORE)

questions.question_text: Which commands can run on both search heads and indexers?

choices.B: A comma before the nested macro.
choices.A: Double tick marks around the nested macro.
choices.D: A pipe character before the nested macro.
choices.C: Square brackets around the nested macro.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This question follows a best practice and it isn't true for all. But if the macro starts with a generating command (or any command) you have to put | before calling the macro

Example:
`macro` = stats count by something
| `macro`

There could be confusion between pipe and square brackets; just to be apparent, it is a pipe.
sourcetype=access_* | `mymacro`

questions.question_text: If a nested macro expands to a search string that begins with a generating command, what additional syntax is needed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
When any search is ran the parsing stage expands the macro. There is no reason they cant be nested

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
For example
macro(1) -> `macro` => index=web sourcetype=access_combine `macro2($field$)`
macro2(1) -> `macro2` | stats count by $field$

see that the first macro (outer macro) is receiving the $field$ argument and passing to the second macro (inner macro)

Correct answer is D.
option A, it is not the correct answer to the question about passing an argument value to an inner macro. Option A suggests that the argument value may be passed to the outer macro, but the question asks about passing the argument value to the inner macro.

questions.question_text: When using a nested search macro, how can an argument value be passed to the inner macro?

choices.D: The argument value must be specified in the outer macro.
choices.B: An argument cannot be used with an inner nested macro.
choices.A: The argument value may be passed to the outer macro.
choices.C: An argument cannot be used with an outer nested macro.
Use greedy operators (.*) instead of non-greedy operators (.*?).
choices.A: Use complex expressions rather than simple ones.

questions.question_text: Which is a regex best practice?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Other answers are the opposite of best practice. No need to extra knowledge on regex.

Selected Answer: A
The makeresults command generates a result with the _time field set to the current time.
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/SearchReference/Makeresults

Selected Answer: A
| makeresults alone generates "_time" only

Selected Answer: A
Makeresults generates a timestamp so you can create an event with that timestamp, mainly for purposes (i.e. testing an alert).
Generates a single event in memory with only the _time field. You can add event fields using eval. Must be the first command in search succeeding a pipe
It generates the specified number of search results in temporary memory. With a single field, _time.

choices.D: The results of the previously run search

questions.question_text: What does the query | makeresults generate?
